sobre.texto:
Dr. Leiza Loiane Hollas
Cardiovascular Surgery
Graduated in Medicine from the Pontifical Catholic University of Paraná (2018).

She completed her medical residency in Cardiovascular Surgery at the Brazilian Red Cross Hospital - Paraná. Her main areas of practice include cardiovascular surgery, surgical simulation, and valvular surgery.

She is a scientific researcher with articles published in Brazilian journals and scientific magazines.

Member of The Valve Club, an organization focused on spreading knowledge and science through posts about Valvular Heart Disease and Structural Heart Disease — a growing area of interest in Cardiology.

card1.texto: Maintain absolute fasting for 8 hours before surgery, including water.

card2.texto: Inform your doctor about all medications used and known allergies.

card3.texto: Bring a photo ID, recent tests, and insurance authorization if applicable.

card4.texto: Take a shower with antiseptic soap the night before and the day of surgery.

card1.texto: Confirm your full name before any exams or procedures. Keep the ID bracelet until discharge.

card2.texto: Do not provide data or make payments over the phone. Contact the hospital’s cashier for questions.

card1.texto: Even if you feel fine, call the nursing team before getting up.

card2.texto: Keep personal items within reach and the call button accessible.

card1.texto: After using the bathroom, before meals, and when entering or leaving the hospital. Use 70% alcohol if not visibly dirty.

card2.texto: Ask companions and visitors to clean their hands frequently too.

card1.texto: AAS, Clopidogrel, Marevan, Marcoumar, Eliquis must be suspended 5 days before surgery. Rivaroxaban, 2 days before. Always follow medical advice!

card2.texto: Hospitalize the day before surgery at 2 PM. Bring documents, exams, authorization, and personal items.

card3.texto: Remove false eyelashes, gel nails, piercings, spacers, hair extensions, and valuables.

card4.texto: After insurance approval, it is necessary to schedule the pre-anesthetic evaluation in advance.

card1.texto: Yes, one companion over 18 is allowed during hospitalization.

card2.texto: Bringing outside food is not allowed without permission from the nutrition team.

card3.texto: Visits are allowed from 2 PM to 8 PM. Under 16s are not allowed in ICUs.

artigos.titulo: Basic Manual of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery by LACTCV
artigos.resumo: The purpose is to provide basic knowledge of thoracic and cardiovascular surgery, especially for medical students, in a didactic way. In the pages of the “Basic Manual of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery by LACTCV,” you will begin a journey of deepening in basic and essential principles. We hope you enjoy the reading and see this book as a first step in the pursuit of excellence that surgery demands.

artigos.titulo: Conventional surgical approach after a Mitraclip failure
artigos.resumo: The growing incidence of valvular structural heart diseases follows the aging population. There is a high demand for both conventional and minimally invasive (transcatheter) interventions to reduce morbidity and mortality.

artigos.titulo: Relevant publications on mitral valve surgery
artigos.resumo: The mitral valve has always fascinated cardiac surgeons. Its precise function and complex anatomy make it an area of significant medical interest. Treatment history begins in 1923 at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital.

artigos.titulo: The surgeon’s view on bioprosthetic valve dysfunction
artigos.resumo: The increase in valvular heart disease correlates with aging and rheumatic fever. There's an increasing demand for valve interventions, especially among younger patients.
In 1900, Dr. William Osler stated: 'There is no disease more humbling than aortic aneurysms.' This remains true, as aortic diseases continue to be a major clinical-surgical challenge.

artigos.titulo: The surgeon’s view on tricuspid valve disease
artigos.resumo: Intervention is clearly indicated when combined with mitral or aortic valve surgery. Isolated tricuspid disease intervention remains controversial, more frequent in cases of stenosis.
